88.title: Pixel 3a front camera repeated failure
88.content: My Pixel 3a front (selfie) camera stopped working in late November 2020.  I tried different camera apps, doing a factory reset on the phone, and all of the other troubleshooting steps from Google.  None of them made any difference, so I was advised to send my phone to a Google authorized repair partner (Ubreakifix was the only option in Canada) for out of warranty repair.  They replaced the front camera module and midframe (which I assume was damaged in disassembly) and it worked great until March 2021.  Suddenly the front camera stopped functioning again - giving me the same "Something went wrong" message in the camera app when I try to switch to the front camera.  As in November, it doesn't work in other apps either.  In early April, I noticed the bottom right corner of the display is lifting away from the midframe and I started getting "phone is getting too warm" messages occasionally when using the phone in bright sun.  I'm rather frustrated as I spent about $250 for the repair and it seems like the camera modules are prone to failure based on anecdotal evidence online.  I'm not thrilled about the idea of shelling out more to repair this again, only to wonder if the camera module will fail again.  I'm going to try to make my case to the Ubreakifix franchise to give me a break on it, but since it's outside of their 90 day warranty, I don't think I have a leg to stand on.  I do suspect something was wrong with the replacement midframe/adhesive or application thereof since the display is separating from it, but I don't know if that's a factor in the second camera failure.  Any thoughts?

112.title: Pixel 4a front-facing camera not focusing correctly on subject (FIX)
112.content:
The Pixel 4a has a well-documented problem with the Pixel 4a front-facing (selfie) camera not being focused on the subject.  It is fixed focused 10 feet behind the subject, even at the recommended distance of 18" or more - the subject remains out of focus and blurry while the background is crisply in focus.

Here's a test my professional video engineer dad ran on the 4a front-facing camera:

"The problem is a design or manufacturing fault.  Here are photos of the Pixel front facing camera as delivered and with a +2 or +3 close-up filter.  There are focus star charts at the subject distance of 14" and also in the background at 9 feet.  As set at the factory the background is more or less in focus, but the subject is not.  It's better with a +2 close-up filter taped over the camera lens, and perfect with a +3 close-up filter.  Clearly the camera is not focused properly, either because the wrong focal length was spec'd or delivered for the camera, or because the lens is too close to the sensor.  The simplest fix for existing phones, under the circumstances, would be for Google to admit the camera has a fault, and send a small stick-on +3 close-up filter to place over the camera lens to anyone who requests one."

Step up Google, and make good on your defective camera.

203.title: Pixel 4a's rear camera is broken and Google does not honor warranty
203.content:
I am currently living in Korea, so I bought Pixel 4a through a friend in the U.S. in December. (He sent me the device which is he bought from the Google Store.) 

But around February, the back camera suddenly died black and it didn't work. Whenever I open the camera app, only got a pop-up message telling me to turn off and turn on the app again. There was also a problem that flashlight icon was grayed out and stated in being used. 

I've tried all the possible solutions google mentioned in help center. also searched in the Google community and found many people suffering same issues like me, but there was no clear solution. so I finally contacted Google Support to get an RMA. 

When I contacted them, they told me my IMEI number was blocked. However, when I checked my IMEI on another IMEI checking website(even google store page), it didn't say it was blocked. anyway Google told me to take over ownership from a friend because the email account and the owner did not match, and I asked my friend to transfer. Then they asked me to start a new chat again so that they can  authenticate my device and check the ownership. I did that and waited for their response.

But all of a sudden, they responded "We have conducted an investigation and determined that this device is not eligible for a warranty replacement/refund due to previous illicit activity. We recommend you reach out to the place where you purchased this device, as they may be able to provide you with further information." 

Whenever I asked them what kind of illicit activity I was being accused, they only send the same answer over and over. They're driving me crazy. I'm told to reach out the place I bought it from but I bought it from you Google store! who do you want me to contact?  I've been suffering for two months and losing hope... All I want is RMA with warranty.

225.title: Photos dates wrong and photos won't delete
225.content:
I have been having problems with camera/photos for a couple of weeks. I concluded a long chat session with a Google rep but he was unable to fix it.I have also sent this in as Feedback from my Google Pixel 4a phone.
  These are the issues:
  (1) Deleting photos and videos on the Google Photos 'roll' is problematic. Some will not delete at all. Some remain but are blurry, out if focus, when I know that the original photo was in-focus. Some stay on the photo directory as grey squares; in other words they take up space on then 'roll' but there is no image.
  (2) Images/thumbnails on the Google Photos directory/roll have a right arrow in the middle, indicating that they are videos. When that thumbnail is tapped the full image fills the screen, the arrow is still there. When the arrow is tapped nothing happens, i.e. no video plays, the still image stays. I am not 100% sure that the image ever was a video-- I think it was (there are many fake video icons, it's not just one) but it is possible that it was a still in the first place and a video icon was somehow added.
  (3) The dates of many photos have been changed. Photos that I know for certain were taken in Nov, Dec, Jan, and Feb are appearing under Oct 25th or 27th, etc.The 'roll' is really a mess. Some images from long ago, prior to October, are dumped in the Oct 27th (or nearby date) listing. It's ridiculous. And a big mess.
  Has anyone else experienced these problems?

Thanks.

245.title: Blurry photos using "Far" Focus mode in Night Sight
245.content:
In Night Signt, with focus set on "Far", pictures will be consistently blurry: instead of being correctly focused on far items, the camera will be correctly focused for objects at a 1 meter distance approximately.

This brings the main problem: when in astrophotography mode, it is very hard to correctly focus on the sky using autofocus, intuitively I would lock the focus to "far": this however makes all photos consistently blurry as the focus is not being correctly applied, by the app, to infinity.
Some pictures for example:

Taken with Night Sight + focus set to "far"


Taken with Night Sight + focus set to "auto"

Left: Taken with Night Sight with Astrophotography + focus set to "far" (on a tripod)
Right: Taken with Night Sight with Astrophotography + focus set to "auto" (on a tripod)



This seems to be a software issue with the camera (it assumes it is focused to far when set to "far" while it is not. How should I do to fix this problem?

265.title: Pixel 4XL Camera: Hardware or Software issue?
265.content:
Hi everyone - I've recently been having some issues with my camera on my 4XL. I haven't been having much luck narrowing down if it's a hardware or software (camera app) issue and the keywords I've been using and searching for haven't been helping me solve my specific issue. I'm aware of the Pixel 3 "camera shaking fiasco however, mine doesn't seem to be exactly the same. While in video mode or using the view finder to take still pictures for that matter, the "video" rips or tears. This issue also gets recorded on video. The things I've noticed are:
It seems to happen no matter the orientation
It seems to rip/tear more when I pass vertical objects, almost like the stabilization has something to do with it.
If I have my ear near the phone, which is difficult to do, I can sometimes hear the optics clicking, this may mean nothing
My phone is still under warranty until May 2021

297.title: From the seas, to more zzz’s: your new Pixel features
297.content:
We regularly update your Pixel so that it's even more helpful, and even more unique. This latest drop includes the ability to easily access and share Recorder transcriptions, a new way to use the Pixel Camera app underwater and new wallpapers to celebrate International Women's Day. 

The features will begin rolling out to Pixel devices starting on March 1st, continuing in stages over the next two weeks*[1].  Update to the latest Android version and update your Android apps to receive the latest features. Once updated, look out for a notification from the Tips app to learn more about all of the ways your Pixel just got more helpful. 

A more shareable Recorder.
You can now share links to your Recorder files, allowing anyone to hear recordings and see transcripts at recorder.google.com, even if they don’t have a Pixel*[2]. You can also back up recordings to your Google Account to help keep them safe*[3].

Take your Pixel under the sea.
Your Pixel now supports the Universal Smart Phone Housing for scuba diving by Kraken Sports*[4]. Get access to your Pixel’s camera features, like Night Sight, Portrait Mode, and video, directly through Pixel’s Camera app for high-quality images of you and your underwater friends. 

Messaging just got easier and more efficient.
Smart Compose is now available for select messaging apps on your Pixel*[5]. It uses machine learning to help you complete your sentences as you type, so sending and replying to messages is easier than ever.

Wallpapers for cultural moments.
Introducing a new wallpaper collection that will celebrate different cultural moments throughout the year. The wallpapers will feature work from diverse artists around the world.

A more seamless bedtime schedule.
Now when you use the bedtime features in Clock with your Pixel Stand, you’ll see a new and improved bedtime screen, along with redesigned notifications to help you ease into a great night’s sleep*[6].

Summary of Availability per Device:


----------------------------------------------------------------

Disclaimers
*[1] Your Pixel phone will receive feature drops during the applicable Android update and support periods for the phone. See g.co/pixel/updates for details.
*[2] Transcription is available in English only. Recorder sharing requires internet connection and Google Account.
*[3] Cloud storage requires internet connection and a Google Account. 
*[4] Works with Pixel 2 or newer phones. Requires Android R, Camera Update 8.1 (Nov. 2020), Dive Case Connector app for Google Camera, KRH04 or KRH03 Kraken Sports Universal Smart Phone Housing (sold separately). See g.co/pixel/dive-case-connector-setup for more information. Kraken Sports is a registered trademark of Kraken Sports Ontario, Canada.
*[5] US only. English only. Not available on all messaging apps. See g.co/gboardsuggestions for details.
*[6] Not available on Pixel 3a, Pixel 4a, or Pixel 4a (5G). Pixel Stand sold separately. Available only on Pixel phones with wireless charging capability: Pixel 3, Pixel 3 XL, Pixel 4, Pixel 4 XL, and Pixel 5.

383.title: Pixel 5 is temporarily freezing after deleting a photo
383.content:
Hi All,

I am on my second Pixel 5 now and am experiencing an issue in which the phone temporarily freezes after deleting a photo within the google camera or google photos app. 

Steps to reproduce are as followed:

1. Open the camera app
2. Take 4 photos
3. Wait about 10 seconds
2. Review the photos within the camera app
3. Delete the 4th photo

At this point the app displays the 2nd photo ( instead of the 3rd), freezes the phone for about 3-5 seconds, displays the 3rd photo and unfreezes the phone. This is also happening with the google photos app.

I have tried the following:

1. Uninstall all updates
2. Install all updates
3. Run in safe mode
4. Delete all cache and data
5. Factor reset the phone

Nothing above solved the issue. 

I am not running any apps other than the ones installed by default, and this is the second Google Pixel 5 that is experiencing this issue.

At this point I'm thinking about returning the phone for a refund. Support had been back and forth on this; but has not resolved the issue. 

I'm hoping that someone in the community here can shed some light on this issue if they have experienced it. I've always had Google phones and this is my first phone since the Nexus 5 (it served me well). I really want to keep it; but this freezing issue is driving me nuts. 

Thanks!

386.title: Pixel 4XL Photo Names Are All Offset By +4 Hours
386.content:
Since I've upgraded to Android 11, the photo/video naming convention has changed, and not for the better. I see that it has PXL_YYYYMMDD_HHMMSSxxxx.jpg. I don't know what those last 4 digits are. Anyway, since the update, the HHMM has been offset by +4 hours, and there's no way to change it. I've tried manually changing time zones, changing the time on my device manually... nothing. If I take a photo at 6am, the name of the file will read 1000 for HHMM. It's incredibly aggravating.

I've tried turning off location globally, turning it off in the Google Camera app itself, still nothing. It's like the camera app is pulling my time zone data from somewhere else.

I should also add that the timestamp in the metadata shows the correct time for when the photo was taken. It's just the actual filename that is offset.

I've also tried using a different app, like Open Camera, and the filenames are correct. The problem seems to only be with Google Camera.

472.title: Pixel 5 camera quality is poor!
472.content: I have had several pixel phones and google devices in the past. Most recently, switched from the pixel 3. The pixel 3's camera is fantastic! I purchased two Pixel 5 devices and so far the camera quality is horrible. In both the front and rear facing camera I am experiencing the same quality issues. Blurred photos, noise, no clarity or details, etc. It's comparable to the very first digital camera I ever owned in early 2000. I contacted support a few times, they suggested a few soft items and factory reset. This did nothing to resolve the issues. They then suggested to take it to be "fixed" at an authorized store (Ubreakifix). The store did not have parts or believed it would be a hardware issue they could fix. Finally, they offered to replace ONE of the phones? Ok. We will see if the replacement device is better, but I feel it's a fundamental flaw in the current hardware / design. I will come back with an update once the replacement comes, but I am not hopeful. At this point I would not recommend buying a pixel 5 - especially if you use it for your main camera like most people. Worst. Camera. Ever.

588.title: Why are selfies still being retouched with retouching disabled on front camera?
588.content:
Selfies taken using the front camera on my Pixel 5 are being noticeably retouched during image processing, despite face retouching being disabled on my device. It's unclear if this is a bug or intended camera behavior.

I've done some testing on my own and observed that selfies taken with the front facing camera undergo the following changes even with retouching disabled:
general loss of sharpness (smoothing of skin)
removal or reduction of visible blemishes
considerable lightening of skin tone

The result, after processing, is a photo that often looks unnatural, waxy, and overcorrected.

In my own testing, enabling retouching caused the same changes listed above, but moreso. I've also determined that this is not due to the portrait lighting feature, since turning this feature off in google photos produces the original retouched photo.

In addition to feeling like unintended behavior, since the change is highly noticeable and fairly drastic,  it also flies in the face of Google's recent, highly-publicized decision to disable retouching by default on its devices. Unwanted facial retouching can be highly damaging to users' self-image, and it's also causing a general lack of image fidelity—my face looks less detailed, as if the image quality has been downgraded by the device.

I'm including some samples of my testing here:

The first photo is a side-by-side comparison of the before and after images. The top photo is the original image, pre-processing (Screenshot taken from the gallery). The bottom image is the retouched selfie.

This is the processed and visibly retouched image, by itself:


Note the general lack of fidelity when comparing the final image to the original.

Finally, I have attached a recording of my camera app, documenting the process of taking a photo, viewing it in the gallery app, and the image dramatically changing when processing is complete. Note that my face is a completely different tone.

I've discussed this with other pixel users, who have described similar results with their own photos: a loss of image quality, unnatural looking photos, feeling like a mask is being applied to their photos taken with the front-facing camera. This is a worrying trend for me, and for these other users, because it suggests google has incorporated facial retouching directly into its HDR+ image processing where it cannot be disabled by the end user.

Is this behavior intentional? It seems antithetical to google's own public positions on facial retouching. I'd appreciate feedback from other users about this.

649.title: My Pixel 5 Zoom is worse than my Pixel 2
649.content:
Hi,
Just sharing something I found interesting. I just compared 2 photos side by side from my old Pixel 2 against my pixel 5. Both photos were pointed at the same subject and at the same zoom level (3.2x). The results were not what I expected. Both phones were running the stock camera app with the same version #.
The pixel 2 was taking clearer and shaper photos than the pixel 5. I know google updated its Super Res Zoom algorithms with Google camera 8, but man, its actually worse than not having it. Pixel 2 doesnt support super res zoom so I dont understand how its taking better photos.
The problem is that the pixel 5 is creating really pixelated "checkerboard" patterns around text and objects and the pixel 2 does not seem to do this, resulting in a clearer image.
Im getting more and more disappointed by this phone and regretting my purchase. The only reason I buy pixel devices is for the camera and stock android. But more so for the former.
Anyone else notice this? I will post a link to some images to highlight the differences.
Link to comparison https://imgur.com/gallery/ydKlB3u

676.title: Astrophotography mode no longer turns on on Pixel 4 XL
676.content:
Astrophotography mode no longer turns on on my Pixel 4 XL.

When I leave the phone perfectly still on a tripod in the dark at night, and switch to Night Sight mode in the Camera app, nothing happens. Astrophotography mode doesn't turn on automatically, no confirmation toast messages are displayed, and there's no indication the mode is active. Tapping the shutter in the app just takes an ordinary Night Sight mode shot.

Here's how to reproduce the issue:

when the sky is dark, bring a photo tripod at a place facing the night sky
clasp the phone to the tripod
point the phone to the sky
on the phone, open the Camera app
in the Camera app, switch to Night Sight mode

At this point, nothing happens and Astrophotography mode doesn't turn on.

Astrophotography mode worked fine until early September 2020 with exactly the same setup and observing location. I've tried again a couple of nights ago when night sky was even darker.

In mid October I experienced another Astrophotography mode issue. Astrophotography mode still turned on, but the Camera app took only short exposures up to a few tens of seconds that didn't last until the full 4 minutes Astrophotography mode supports.

I'm using a Pixel 4 XL with Android 11 and version 8.1.011.342784911 of the Google Camera app.

700.title: Pixel 3 camera updates regarding zoom and panorama-- actually downgrades!
700.content:
It seems Google has pushed a few "upgrades" in recent "security" updates which have all been affecting the Pixel 3 camera's user friendliness.
One issue has been about the panorma feature now only available in vertical mode, even if you have auto-rotate function turned on. I only ever take horizontal panoramas, and now Google makes me take these using vertical mode, which is so stupid!

But the main reason for this post: before the recent "upgrade", the camera used to have a soft sliding key up and down with 7x the zoom. Now: depending on night mode or regular camera mode, you're only given two options-- 1x or 2x. How is this an upgrade?!  Not only that, there used to be another slide meter on the top side of the camera viewfinder which allowed you to maneuver light/exposure.  Now, that feature is hidden or not available.

819.title: What camera mode is best for taking pictures of black cats or dogs?
819.content:
I have a Pixel 2 XL and am having a hard time getting the camera to focus properly and take good pictures of my foster kitten, which I need for his personal ad. Usually the camera on this phone takes excellent kitten pictures in varying levels of light and activity. This kitten has dark brown to black fur. Typically dark cats are typically harder to photograph, though I have one that is mostly black that I regularly get great pictures of. I've watched a variety of videos on how to improve the pictures (direct sunlight, simple background, no flash, adjust exposure, focus on eyes). Still, it's not helping. 

I've tried portrait and the regular camera mode, as well as adjusting the exposure and shooting with direct sunlight on the cat and behind me. I'm tapping the screen to focus. Is it simply too dark or that I need additional direct light on him? Other than a couple of pictures, most came out blurry or low detail, which you can see in the gallery of pictures I took today. Any thoughts on how to get my little guy some great pictures so he can find a good family to adopt him? With kittens, time is of the essence, because they're most adoptable when they're really tiny and cute. 

Also - a Black Cat Photo Mode (or black dog) would be a brilliant feature for Pixel phone cameras to have.

868.title: Pixel 4xl Front camera freezing when zoomed in
868.content:
This issue has persisted for me on EVERY app that utilizes my camera (instagram, messenger, facebook, the native android camera app, etc) since the last major android update.

Please fix this google. This phone has been great for the most part, but this is a huge let down.

993.title: Pixel 3/XL Camera Color Balance Defect still not corrected nearly a year later
993.content:
There are continuing complaints about the removal of color balance correction on Pixel phones. As of this date, nearly a year later, Google has demonstrated that they do not have the technical expertise to correct the "automatic" software  color balance issues (they appear to have gotten worse with the most recent OS updates) and "for whatever reasons" will not add back color balance adjustments, a foundation, expected requirement for taking quality images in any camera and a reason why so many advanced amateur and professional photographers selected Pixel. Reluctance to interact with the user base is disconcerting.

Google cannot claim it's camera's produce high quality JPG images if it's software is unable to manage color balance correctly. Resorting to the use of RAW images is no excuse.

As Pixel owners, if camera image quality was a deciding purchasing factor, and Google will not fix the problem, we have to make a decision to continue with defective cameras (this is a defect), or move to another manufacturers device. While we're getting fairly sharp, technically corrected images, the color balance issue makes them look like cheap smartphone camera's from years past, and today almost any other manufacturers camera's provide a more pleasing image. Don't you feel embarrassed when in the past people complimented you on the image quality and now ask you what happened to these images, why so poor? You can only say, well it's Google.

We no longer have a product that justifies its asking price. It's time to move on for those who need the best quality images in their life applications.

1036.title: Camera - Sequence Composition using 4K video
1036.content:
Some Panasonic Lumix cameras allow you to shoot a 4K clip, and then build an image they call a Sequence Composition.  Sequence Composition selects multiple frames from a video clip and stacks that into a single image (for obvious reasons the camera needs to be stationary).

I've seen Google Photos do this a few times with a burst of photos. 

I think it would be a cool feature to add to the neato capabilities the Pixel has.

1131.title: Google Camera app on Pixel 3 crashing since July 4
1131.content:
As of July 4 on my Pixel 3 my camera app crashes every time I attempt to open it. Also, as with many other comments I've seen online, my flashlight app is greyed out and cannot be turned on. Clearly the two are tied together.

Of note, I am able to open Snapchat and use my selfie cam within the app. When in Snapchat there is no longer an option to switch to the back facing camera. 

I have tried clearing the data and the cache for the Google Camera app, uninstalling and reinstalling the Google Camera app, removing all permissions from third party apps to the camera, restarting my device multiple times, restarting my device in safe mode, clearing the data and cache of my Google Photo app, and I installed the July 5 software update as of just this morning, all with no resolution.

I contacted Google's support via message option and was told that the only option left is a factory restart (which of course is only part of the trouble shooting options and as with any issue with a phone I've ever had will very likely do nothing to help, but I'm not able to try this this morning as I am not in a position to back anything up so I did not do so as of yet) and that since I'm out of warranty I am unable to send my phone in even if the factory restart does not resolve the issue. 

I informed them I've sent status updates multiple times since this started and inquired as to whether this is a known issue being addressed. Of course I was told it is not and that there is no work being done on what is clearly a software issue. I was told that they would pass on my issue and that "there are many user reported issues coming through that need to be addressed" but that they would pass this on at my request. 

I mentioned the fact that there was quite a bit of reporting done on the Pixel 2 camera issues and that if I have this issue then clearly others do as well and this has been reported to them, but as always they are going to play ignorant.

Once again Google is not owning up to software issues and is shoving them under the rug.

To add insult to injury the person "helping" me thanked me for my understanding, as if I had any choice in the matter.

Thank you, Google, for charging exorbitant prices for flagship phones that you do not support.

1177.title: Pixel 3a photos disappearing?
1177.content:
I have a Pixel 3a that is just 62 days old now. I gave it to my wife as a gift before our baby was born so she could take and store better photos of our baby.

This morning we discovered that the phone made all of our photos more than two days old completely disappear. They are not deleted, they are not in the trash, they are just simply gone.

I have gone through Google Support who tried to help but we weren't able to recover the photos nor we were able to confirm it won't happen again.

Here is all of the information that we can give up front:
- I have only the native apps on the phone (Google Camera and Google Photos).
- I did not do a backup to Google photos. I will do it in the future but realistically it shouldn't be necessary on a 62 day old phone. I'd like to keep my photos stored on the device so I can view them regardless of data or Wi-Fi connection.
- I have restarted the phone a couple of times.
- I have deleted the cache for the Photos and Camera apps, as well as I uninstalled the updates and reinstalled them.
- I have searched for the photos through the "Files" app and through "Storage". I found some of the old thumbnails but they were deleting themselves quickly as well.
- The photos were not in the trash. A bunch of photos that were supposed to be there (that I put there just yesterday) were there. When I went back in to make sure the photos I wanted weren't in there, trash had deleted all of the photos on its own, even ones only a few hours old.
- I have checked the app permissions and they are all good.
- So far Google's only advice is to wait to see how frequently our 62 day old phone fails. I am of the opinion that just once in 62 days is too often but apparently Google thinks that's acceptable.
- Both Photos and Camera had updates just 16 hours ago.

Has anyone else had this issue? Did you resolve it? If so, how? Can we expect it to continue to fail?

We have very little confidence in this product now.

Any help at all would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you,

Bernie (and Christine)

Background and description

1247.title: Front-facing camera: blurry and terrible static noise

This has been written about in numerous other places with no clear solution. It is something that seems to be a software issue, not a hardware issue.

It happened randomly ~4 months ago. I wasn't using the front-facing camera much then (pre-coronavirus), so I didn't make a big deal of it.

I've tried other solutions written about on other threads and Reddit, including clearing my camera's cache (in storage), deleting my phone's voice match for Google Assistant (which I now have off), removed Google Home entirely, etc.

Any other troubleshooting tips for this? Help would be infinitely appreciated; this issue is horribly annoying and is a daily problem now.

I won't be clearing my entire storage (too annoying). But one thing that's interesting is that I did boot my phone in safe mode and this still happened.

So I'm wondering if it's some sort of Android / Pixel software setting I can roll back - rather than an app causing a problem.

I am not interested in sending my phone in for a refurbished model.

And naturally, during this pandemic, Google's 1:1 support is unavailable and their response time is...well, not helpful.

1251.title: Pixel 3 Camera Not Focusing
1251.content:
I am having a problem with the camera on my Pixel 3. It was working fine yesterday, and all of a sudden, this morning it would no longer focus when taking a picture. At first I thought that this was just a random fluke, so I rebooted the phone, which didn't fix it. I went on to clear the storage and cache folder of the Google camera app, restart the phone in safe mode, force stop any apps that may have been using the camera, none of which worked. 

I thought at first that this could be related to the April security update I received late last night, and began talking to my friend who has a Pixel 3 XL. He mentioned that this morning, his camera also would no longer focus. However, he has had the April update for quite a while longer than I have. We tried ruling out apps that were updated or installed since last night, which included Android accessibility features, Android System WebView, and the device customizations app -- we tried uninstalling updates to these but that did not fix the issue.

I was about to throw in the towel on this being a hardware issue until my buddy mentioned his phone having the same exact issue, at the same exact time. I am wondering if anyone else has experienced this issue. Unfortunately, Google Support is not exactly helpful in this scenario -- the best piece of advice they could give was to just send the phone into the repair depot or buy a Pixel 4 and trade this in.

1261.title: Sunset/golden hour photos colors are inaccurate / washed-out
1261.content:
Before sunset the other night, I confirmed an issue regarding color accuracy of clouds and landscape on my Pixel 3a. When focusing on a particularly beautiful array of pink clouds, the camera could not pick up what I was clearly seeing. The clouds and sky had an orange tint, were less defined, and the greenery below was dark and also less defined.

I notice that sometimes the camera looks to fall short of accuracy in full daylight when I shoot, but then the algorithm seems to correct and the output is great.

This was not the case here, as shown in the first pic below.

HOWEVER, I stumbled upon a short-term fix, which indicated to me that there is an issue that might be resolved. 

That fix was to point the camera at the ground, then raise it quickly and snap a shot before it could focus and washout the picture. It was the photographer's equivalent of taking shots like a quick-drawing, Wild West cowboy in a shootout outside the saloon. Not the best scenario for making a composition, or much else.

Three result was the second photo below, a pretty decent shot considering the quick, sweeping action I had to make to take it, and much truer to what my eyes saw.

Can anyone steer me towards a fix so I don't have to act like a outlaw at the ok corral when I want to take pics at sunset?

1283.title: Greenish bars in product photos -- CFL lighting issue? Camera setting?
1283.content:
Searched the posts, but all the hits seem to be for different issues. I'm a bookseller using my phone for product photography. In my photos I'm getting three or four greenish-brown vertical bars of discoloration. Sometimes they move horizontally while I'm waiting to take the shot. I experienced this once on an older Galaxy phone (7?) while using a 3rd party camera app but it went away when I switched back to the regular camera, so wondered if there's a setting I'm missing in the Google camera or a different camera app that would process it differently?

I'm using CFL desktop lamps in a flourescent-lit warehouse space, same as I was with my previous Galaxy S9 that didn't have an issue with it. All my other photos elsewhere look great. I can get the bars to disappear by nudging up the brightness bar on the right, but it's a tightrope to over-exposure. 

Below is a quick shot of what I'm usually getting. I know I need a better lighting setup (soon), but the end pics actually look great after adjusting white balance and knocking out the background in post. The discolored bars remain, though, so any thoughts on getting rid of them would be amazing.

1286.title: Pixel 2 XL Camera Fails to open or Load
1286.content:
OK so I've seen lots of posts about the Pixel 2 Camera failing after a recent update. 

I was one of the people affected by this issue. my camera on my Pixel 2 XL didn't suddenly stop working, it started to fail to load a few times and then it started to fail to load a lot of the time. Finally, after a few weeks, it got to the point where the camera failed to load at all.

 I contacted support and did all the normal tricks like try a different app, clear cache, uninstall updates, wipe phone none of these things worked. 

The only workaround I found was to wave a small neodymium magnet near the camera while opening the app. This would allow the camera to open.  Once the app was open you need to move the magnet away from the phone or the focus would go all wobbly. 

After a few more weeks of this, I found it really annoying to have to remember to carry a magnet around in my pocket. I logged a new call with google and they instructed me to RMA the device. about a week and a bit later I received a refurbished phone from google (which was actually pretty nice since the phone was out of warranty by about a month.) 

Now this phone was way behind in patches. So as a test I would update and then test the camera and update again and test the camera (all previous apps were loaded) 

QP1A.191005.007a1 OK Tested 6 times
QP1A.191105.004 OK Tested 6 times
QQ1A.191205.008 OK Tested 6 times
QQ2A.200305.002 OK Tested 6 times

I actually don't think this is a software update issue. I believe the actuator arm of the camera wears out after about 2 years of heavy use.  I use my camera daily since it's the one I have on me. 

I did previously post the logcats where it said the actuator arm failed but the post has since been deleted by someone else. 

So for anyone else out there with a similar pixel 2 camera issue. have you logged it with google?

1290.title: Front facing camera is distorting/"squishing" images containing faces. Pixel3
1290.content:
Front facing camera "squishes" faces during processing. The change is visible if you open the photo before it's done processing, you. Can see it "squish" when it's finished processing.

I found this post (will attach) which explains as long as the face stays in the center of the vertical golden ratio lines, it will not be distorted. However, if the face appears to left or right of those vertical lines, it is "squished" after photo processes.

Very annoying/impossible to take a selfie with a friend without ending up with round, distorted faces.

1327.title: Panning video is choppy
1327.content:
When taking video in either 1080p or 4K, panning causes video to be choppy or "stutter". This only happened within the last few updates. I'm not sure if there is an issue with read/write speed to the internal storage or software issues within the Google Camera itself. It's becoming more and more prevalent recently and detracts from taking nice clear video of those special moments. Video quality has usually been quite smooth but not recently. 

To replicate, take video in either 1080p or 4K and pan slight to the right then left (or vice versa). What you see is what you get essentially. The panning live with choppy or stuttering is shown on playback. I'd expect there to be a fluid video picture as opposed to what I'm currently seeing.

I'd almost describe it as slight "jitter". I'm taking the video indoors under daylight LED lights (which are quite bright). I've seen this happen outside in complete sunlight as well.

1352.title: How do I stop and fix my pixel 3 XL camera from distorting images ?
1352.content:
Starting yesterday, the front and rear camera on my Pixel 3 XL has started to "process" images and distort them, making everything look very wide and strange looking. After taking a picture, I'll see the way it's supposed to look and then it will say "processing" and distort the image. 

The HDR is turned off. I've never had this issue with the front facing camera with the HDR off, and this is the first time I have experienced this with the rear camera. Everything was normal prior to yesterday. I contacted a Google rep via chat on the Pixel, and the issue was not resolved.

We tried updating the stock camera google app and Google photos.
We uninstalled updates for both apps.
Reinstalled them.
Entered the phone in safe mode.
Made sure my phone is updated (has been running Android 10 for maybe a week now?) 
Nothing has helped. Any help is appreciated!

UPDATE: I fixed this issue a few days after posting this by uninstalling recent apps. This made me realize that it was a permission issue.  

After pinpointing which application it was, I went into the device settings and turned off permissions from applications for the "camera". 

Worked fine until today, (December). Will update if I find more solutions...

1353.title: GCam "touch to focus" is unreliable and has many issues
1353.content:
It's been like this for months. Nothing has been fixed.
Touch to focus often does not respond to you pressing or has a delay, the focus often fails to focus, where you touch. Then a lock button appears at the top, which is just as unresponsive.
And suddenly from a slow paced phone, it become an F1 phone, when it comes to hide the lock button, if you spent time trying to get it to focus, then if you fail to press lock button on first try in 2 seconds, then you can start over.

On top of that, if you use touch to focus with flash on, then the exposure is locked when the flash is off, and it doesn't even use flash to focus. It's surprising that the best camera phone has arguably the worst manual focusing. It's only to be used as a point and shoot phone, which it's really good for.

For comparison Nexus phones had a reliable touch&hold to lock focus and exposure. This is replaced by lens camera, which I personally only activate from Google Assistant button, not from camera.

Can we finally get a better solution, please?

1357.title: Pixel 2 Rear Camera Autofocus Issues then Stopped Working; Selfie Camera Still Fine
1357.content:
Hi, I have a Pixel 2 that is almost two years old.

This week the rear camera began having autofocus issues. The focus looked like it was stuck in macro mode. It'd focus on extremely close objects but not close to distant objects. When shooting video, the camera would go in and out of focus. Closing and reopening the app solved the focus issues.

Last night, launching the camera app stopped working altogether. Clicking the camera icon results in the app launching then immediately dying. Sometimes there's an error message, sometimes there's a request for feedback, but most of the time the app just silently dies.

If I hold down the camera app icon and select take a selfie, the camera app usually launches and works. this leads me to believe that whatever is happening is limited to the rear camera.

Sometimes if I force stop the camera app then open it up a bunch of times (four to ten), the rear camera will start working perfectly again. The next time I go to use the rear camera though, the app starts the crashing again.

Camera app version is 6.2.030.244457635. I tried clearing cache, clearing storage, safe mode, everything short of a factory reset with no success.

This seems to be a fairly widespread problem. What gives and how do I go about getting it fixed?

If we don't have 4K 60 on Pixel phones, then please make 1080p better!

1479.title: Why are close-up selfies sharper on the Pixel 3 than the Pixel 4?
1479.content:
Selfies taken with the Pixel 4 are not nearly as sharp as those taken with the Pixel 3. 

I've been playing around with this for hours now, and the problem seems isolated to just the front-facing camera. I haven't been able to test this outside with the sunlight, but I used all of the lights in my house and I still get the same result.

I'll provide two photos, the first being taken with the Pixel 3, the second with the Pixel 4.
You can easily see the detail in the facial hair on the Pixel 3 as you zoom in, but on the Pixel 4, all of the detail is somewhat lost and, for lack of a better word, "blurry." And it's no small difference, it's massive.

This has been consistent regardless of the use of portrait mode or facial retouching. 

However, as I pull the camera further away from my face, the pixel 3 does seem to lose its sharpness and the pixel 4 provides a close, if not better, image. Is this a software issue, or is this a hardware issue? How did Google not test these cameras out more, and why aren't there more people talking about this?

Either way, this is super frustrating. Just another reason for me to wonder why I even bothered upgrading.

1481.title: Pixel 4 XL Microphone Audio Artifacts in Video Recording - Here We Go Again
1481.content:
So, the Pixel team still hasn't learned its lesson with how to handle microphones on smartphones, apparently. ;)

I was documenting an iOS 13.2 (!) bug while, inadvertently, showcasing a different kind of issue on the device with which I chose to record (the Pixel 4 XL, latest public version of Camera app - 7.2). 

https://youtu.be/wmhcF7G_ae8

Take a listen. You can hear a weird, dull popping, at random times - like something was tapping the mic, but it wasn't. Unless it was a ghost? LOL 

One hand was swiping the iPad screen, the other was holding onto the phone - in a silent room, indoors. 

The mic anomalies are quite evident toward the tail end (very end) of the video. You can also hear the pops when I say "okay" toward the middle. Then, possibly, there's also light crackle. 

Here we go again... the mic on the Pixel 4 still needs tweaking (like mics on earlier Pixels did).

1521.title: Your phone uses ELS only when you call or text an emergency number. During your emergency call, ELS
1521.content:
Your phone uses ELS only when you call or text an emergency number.
During your emergency call, ELS may use Google Location Services and other information to obtain the most accurate location possible for the device.
Your phone sends the location to authorized emergency partners for the purpose of helping emergency services locate you. Your location is sent directly from your phone to emergency partners, not through Google.
After a completed emergency call or text during which ELS was active, your phone sends usage and analytics data to Google for the purpose of analyzing how well ELS is working. This information doesn't identify you and Google doesn't use it to identify you.

I opened the photo from the camera album in photos and shared the photo to gmail and sent it to her, which she said she didn't have an attachment. I tried again as watched as I did it. I then did a normal restart on my phone and went back to the same photo. This time when I swiped up to see the file size my phone starting quickly flashing through photos, about one each 1/4 of a second. When I finally got my phone to go to the home screen I went back in to my camera album and every photo from the last year was gone.

To answer, no, my backup was not turned on so please move beyond that. Google support by phone last night had no answer other than to have me search for a video on YouTube that ended up being an ad for some software, which I thought was pretty unprofessional. They honestly act like this had never happened and have no idea what occurred. 

There must be a way to run a legitimate data recovery on my phone, right? My storage dropped by about 15Gb when this happened. The data has to still be there. I tried a basic recovery app from the play store and as it ran I could see thumbnails of the missing photos but the app was so garbage it either didn't complete or is a basic version to have you buy the upgrade one. 

Has anyone else seen this situation or know if there an actual way to run a recovery on the data?

1597.title: Terribly slow customer support
1597.content:
I just got myself a Pixel 3 that freezes while taking pictures. Additionally, it takes many hours (or even days) for pictures to be populated in photos. 
I started a support chat, where after some very basic troubleshooting, they asked me to factory reset the phone. 
I escalated as I did not think sufficient troubleshooting was done before the ask. I was told a supervisor would get back to me. The supervisor got back to me after 1 FULL day and parroted the exact same line - just saying that they absolutely needed me to do a factory reset. If that did not fix it, they would look into what else could be done. 

Being an engineer, I asked as to what other troubleshooting were they looking for. 12 hours later, he responds saying that they are trying to understand if it is a HW or SW issue. If the issue persisted, he vaguely said he would look into talking about warranty options.

I have now done a factory reset and the issue still exists. I reached out via chat and was told that support cannot help as it is with a specialist. The specialist will get back to me within 24-48 hours! 

There is absolutely no way to get a faster response.

I am stunned that a company the size of google has such limited staff that they take 24-48 hours to respond, and they have such a poor support structure that no one deviates from a very set script - repeating and parroting the same lines again and again.

At this point, I am just frustrated with the Pixel support experience and wanted to share these experiences with the broader audience so people know what to expect!

1607.title: Portrait Mode - Preview bounces to previous photo taken
1607.content:
This may be difficult to explain but I seem to be having issues where reviewing the portrait photo taken causes a "bounce back" to the previous photo. Example, I'll take one portrait photo, review it and it appears fine. The next one I take, I'll click on the review icon and while it shows "Processing"....once it appears to complete, it bounces back to the previous photo I took (whether it be a portrait photo or not). I tested it a few times and it seems to happen intermittently. I just want to see if others are experiencing this. 

I suggest testing should be done by taking one portrait photo then review it. Then immediately take another one (or two) and see if the image you review is the previous one. The latest photo you just took will be saved, but you'll have to move an image ahead to see it.

Thanks for any confirmations on the same issue! Pixel 3 with July patch has been applied.

1628.title: Pixel 3a sometimes crashes and suddenly restarts when using the flash on the camera. Any ideas why??
1628.content:
I have a Pixel 3a that sometimes has an issue when using the flash on the camera that causes the phone to suddenly shut off/reboot. Usually, it's when I try to rapidly take multiple photos using the flash (within a couple seconds of each other), but it will sometimes have the problem even when just using the flash to take a single photo. To the best of my recollection, I have not changed any of the camera settings since I set the phone up, and the phone does not have any other issues. Everything else on the phone works properly and smoothly (other than the camera not focusing as quickly and accurately as it usually does; but this is not a big deal).

I don't want to have to do a factory reset, but is it possible that a factory rest might help to resolve this issue? Also, I have cleared the cache on the Camera app multiple times, but the problem with using the flash causing the phone to restart still happens sometimes.

I got the Pixel 3a as a gift and don't have the receipt and don't know that I could still get in contact with the person who originally bought it. Is it possible to try to get a Pixel phone fixed under warranty, if you don't have the original receipt to provide? Or, as I suspect, am I SOL when it comes to possibly being able to use the warranty (assuming that it's still active/valid)?

Sorry for the lengthy post. This isn't a major issue; but it it something that is really annoying when it happens, as I have to unexpectedly wait for my phone to reboot. If anyone has any helpful information, ideas or suggestions, a reply would certainly be appreciated.

Also, has anyone else had this camera flash issue with their Pixel 3a device??

1635.title: Pixel 2 XL Google Camera fatal error
1635.content:
Steps I tried to resolve:

1.  I was receiving the fatal error when using the Google Camera app on Android Q Beta.

2.  Cleared the storage (data and cache) and it did not help. 

3.  Uninstalled the app updates and re-updated and it didn't help. 

4.  Restarted into safe mode and it still persisted.

5.  Downloaded another camera app to see if it was purely a software problem - had the same issue.

6.  Factory reset the phone and it did not resolve it.

7.  Opted out of the beta program thinking that may be the issue and factory reset as a result of the downgrade to Android P.  This also did not resolve my problem. 

8.  Repeated steps on Android Pie - no change

Note:  Both cameras on my Pixel 2 XL do not function.



Please assist or point me in the right direction.

Thank you!

1636.title: Camera Pixel 4
1636.content: Compared to the Pixel 3, the fourth family has only one selfie camera and autofocus has been removed from it, this is a minus, why remove it, what works better?  The question is open!  Everyone puts ultra-wide-angle cameras on smartphones, but Google thinks that zoom is more important to users - that's why the Pixel 4 just has a dual camera with the zoom that Apple has had since 2016, although Google insisted that they did not need a second camera for optical zoom, each  year they contradict themselves.  Next year, they will add a third ultra-wide camera and a self-focusing camera with autofocus.  Maybe the main camera in Pixel 4 is very good and it is slightly better than in the previous generation, but it would have been earlier if Apple had not worked out its deep fusion and night mode as it should on iPhone 11, in pixel 4 there is no such separation from competitors as  was earlier in comparison with pixel 2-3 versions, competitors worked out software algorithms.  The video, as it was 4K 30 frames, remained, the competitors already have 4K 60 frames on the front camera, but what the hell is Google?  put another sensor that can record 4K video 60 frames, purely for video, if the IMX 363 is so good for the photo part, leave it too, there is only two cameras in the back, and on the front, put the sensor up to 4K 60 frames, the prices are almost the same  same as Apple, but in the aggregate and in general worse!

1678.title: NR in Google camera (Mark Levoy or IsaacOnCamera)
1678.content: Hi, Mark! First of all I wanted to say a huge thank you for all the hard and tremendous work you've done! Especially considering that there aren't too many people at your Pixel photo team (there are around 12...18 people if I am not mistaken and I thought there were like 100 to 200 people who made this Hdr+ mode come true). There is an issue, however, related with current pixel processing. I remember you once said in your interview that pixel's processing is very tolerate to noise reduction process. I do not know whether you are aware of that or no, but pixels' noise suppression has been becoming more and more intense and now has become one of the strongest in the industry. I'm using the Pixel 1st gen by myself and recently discovered a modded app which allowed adjust the NR processing for one's liking. I was shocked. Photos became like 3 times better with only colour NR turned on. Altogether I understand that there can be some problems with the marketing department which very well may insist on making this NR process that heavy. But still. Maybe there will be a way to add a hidden toggle, like the one with the raw feature somewhere deep in the menu. Because this noise adds professionally edited look to the photos (photos taken in RAW with ,,adited to taste,, label on DPreview often has the similar look as the ones I got with this modded cam app) Thanks for your time and thank you one more time. Just so you know. You and your team inspire people! I believe in you! #teampixel!

1684.title: Original Pixel 3xl, about a month old. Camera focus mechanism failed. RMA phone DOA today.
1684.content:
Bought a Pixel 3xl from the Google store 30-40 days ago.  Everything was going great until Sept. 18th, when the rear facing camera stopped focusing. Contacted support, got an RMA underway, with me placing a temporary hold on my credit card to cover the cross-shipped device.  The RMA phone arrived today, and it was completely DOA. Wouldn't power on, respond to a charger.  Contacted support again about the DOA replacement phone, and after a lot of explaining that it was the refurbished replacement phone that was also non-functional, I was advised to put the refurb phone in the packaging and ship it back using the  label I was e-mailed.  I did so, and now I'm being told that I cannot receive a different RMA phone until the first one arrives at the shipping location, then I can start another RMA.  

In essence I've been without a fully functioning phone for 6 days, and it will be at least another two until they receive the DOA refurb I was sent before I can start yet *another* RMA to get another refurbished phone that may or may not work.  In essence I'm looking at at least another 5-6 days without a fully functioning phone.

The quality control on the refurbished units is obviously non-existent and I'm not sure the next replacement will be functional.   

I'm seriously considering a return/refund and I'll just buy another manufacturer's  phone elsewhere. The support has been nothing short of horrible and frustrating.

1709.title: Photos in camera roll just disappeared
1709.content:
Yesterday I tried taking a video and got a notification that I didn't have enough storage. I started deleting photos but made sure to only delete some that were already backed up (my back up is turned on automatically). After deleting 20-30, I tried deleting more and it said it could not delete them. I went to check my phone storage, and it said the total phone was only at 73%, so something happened to the 27% that was there when I was trying to take the video. I had guessed that I somehow accidentally selected to "Free Up Space", which from my understanding would only have removed photos that were already backed up, so I wasn't worried about it. Later that night I looked at my photos, and all of the photos I had taken that day said "Not backed up. Too big or unknown type" (which didn't make sense because one photo had that message, but the next photo that I had taken 5 minutes later didn't). I searched the internet and someone suggested to clear the cache, and confirmed this would do nothing to harm any photos. I did that and then went back to my "camera" album and only the first 32 photos appeared, and the rest were grey squares. If I went to "photos", it appears that all of the pictures that are saved to my device won't appear, but any photos that aren't, appeared correctly.  In "camera" when I clicked on a photo that isn't displaying, it just gave me a black screen. If I tried editing the photo it said "unable to edit, check your connection". I was connected to both wifi and data so that shouldn't be an issue. If I tried to share the photo, it just gave me a white screen. 

I decided to try restarting my phone because presumably that fixes everything, but then ALL of my photos, except for those first 32 were gone from my camera album. The ones that weren't backed up because they were "too big or unknown type" (even though my camera was the one that took them) were completely gone. 

I'm guessing there's nothing I can do and that those pictures are just gone forever? Any one have any ideas at all of what happened or anything I could do to get those pictures back?

1733.title: TAKE ACTION: Contact Google if upset by Portrait Mode Creating New Folders Issue
1733.content:
I've seen several posts -- here and through Google search, of Pixel phone users complaining about the awful user experience annoyance whereby portrait mode in the stock camera app creating a new and separate folder for every single photo. This is beyond irritating, because if you want to post a photo using a third party app (like Instagram, Twitter or Facebook) you must scroll through a constantly increasing number of folders labeled something like IMG_00000000_000000. In my case, haven taken hundreds of portrait photos, there were hundreds of these folders I needed to delete.

Despite years of complaints, Google and its camera app developers have done nothing in terms of issuing a fix. The problem has persisted throughout each new iteration of the Google phone. This is unacceptable.

PLEASE if you are having this issue, contact Google developers through the camera app, by tapping More--->Settings---->Send feedback and politely ask for an immediate fix. Or consider telling them you will not be purchasing another Pixel phone until this issue is resolved.

When a fixable feature has this many complaints, it's hostile to users for nothing to be done. Let's force Google developers to finally pay attention.

Thanks,

DK

1746.title: Camera has non-linear temporal image distortion and focus instability
1746.content:
Starting a few months after purchase (and continuing now for a couple of months), my pixel 3 rear-facing camera has shown non-linear distortions in the image that flicker in and out, along with very poor focus stability.  Pictures are worth a thousand words:

https://photos.app.goo.gl/6QoC36SX5UAFCAXe6

The first is a still image which needs to be viewed with Motion On.  Notice that the image is generally still, but on the left side there is a non-linear distortion of the image that comes and goes.  I see this effect quite frequently in my photos and on the screen while framing a photo.

The second is a video where I am panning back and forth a bit.  You can see the focus jumping in and out at high frequency and hints of the image non-linear distortion.

I don't see these problems with the front-facing camera.

1751.title: Night Sight for Astrophotography
1751.content:
Hi Google, 

The Night Sight mode in awesome in general, and I love it! But for it kinds of falls short for astrophotography and seems to actually be counter productive. The issue (illustrated on video here: https://www.reddit.com/r/videos/comments/aeuf44/google_pixel_3_night_sight_preprocessing_ruins/) is that Night Sight post-processing makes night sky shots look way worse than what initially comes out of the sensor.

Would you consider an astrophotography mode, where postprocessing is disabled, or at least tuned to retain some of the original deep-sky details? Or, maybe more easily, is there a way to keep the original frames, before they're being post-processed in Night Sight mode?

Thanks!

1840.title: Pixel 3 Camera Crashing

I can restart my phone and sometimes get it to work again, but it's still a one time use.

Other apps that use my camera can work if the camera hasn't been opened already. If I'm using my camera and it won't load, I can go into apps that use the camera and it's crashed there, too.

All of my apps are up to date. I've also tried clearing the camera cache which doesn't seem to do anything. 

I've tried getting Google Assistant to find the issue, but it just searches forever and never finds anything.

When it crashes, the camera screen opens up. It then doesn't show any picture of what I'm looking at. The camera button goes to a darker shade of grey. It thinks for a few seconds and then closes the camera app completely by itself. 

Clearing the camera from recently used apps doesn't do anything.

1841.title: Pixel 2 cameras stopped working after system update
1841.content:
Hello,

I have a Pixel 2 phone which worked perfectly before the last system update.
Right after the update both front and back cameras stopped working. I'm saying it's after the system update because I've tried rolling back the camera software without any result. Phone was not rooted or modified in any way, did not suffer falls or anything like that. All in all, right after the system update the cameras stopped working.

It seems I have similar issues with a lot of other people on the support forum. 
I have tried:
- cleaning lens & laser (no effect, duh)
- restarting the phone
- clearing the app's cache
- updating the apps
- uninstalling / rolling back the apps and reinstalling
- started the phone in safe mode
- sacrificing a lamb (didn't help, but it staved my hunger)

How should I proceed?

Thanks and Regards,

Brad

1897.title: Pixel 2 Deletes Data by Downscaling Photos Without Notifying the User
1897.content: When I first bought my Pixel 2, I was able to upload all photos on the device to Photos at Original quality (as the app says) without affecting my Google Drive storage.  Recently I noticed that Google has started uploading my photos at "High Quality" which tosses out 50-80% of the pixels reducing the quality of the "backed up" photos to an unusable size.  After contacting support (Leo and Rick), they told me I should "free up space" on my device which would have deleted the only remaining originals that I have not already lost.  Google support has not taken ownership of this issue and there is no setting I can change in the Photos app to even change this behavior (because the app assures me, without any settings, that I will have the original quality photo uploaded).  I am posting here (and will post elsewhere if I need to) because the Google support seems so unwilling to fix this issue.  I really thought Google cared more about their customers.

1899.title: Pixel 2 front camera on/off malfunctions
1899.content:
I have a Pixel 2 (128GB) that I purchased about four months ago in almost-new condition off a corporate program. Like many, the front camera began to crash a couple of months into ownership, and I tried all the suggested avenues:
Force stop the camera app, clear data/cache
Restart in safe mode
Look at update rollbacks, try different camera apps, etc.
Reset the device to factory settings

None of these worked, and because I didn't have time to send in the device for repair, I resigned myself to not having a front camera. However, when the device received the PQ2A.190405.003 update, the camera started working again.

Imagine my surprise.

I was equally surprised, however, when I tried opening it this morning (4/14/19), and it's back to not working. I've again tried all the steps that are suggested, but nothing has worked.

What's interesting is that this time the app doesn't crash. When I select the front camera, the app pauses for a second or two, then simply acts like nothing happened and I'm taking a picture with the back camera.

I'm not sure if I'm dealing with a hardware or software issue at this point, to be honest. Has anyone else had this kind of on/off behavior?

1927.title: Fix for Pixel 3 XL????
1927.content: Don't do it. Pixel 3xl has a fatal camera flaw. I read about the glitches before purchasing, but figured everything would be worked out. Google won't do anything unless I send them the phone for 7-10 business days. Best Buy won't help because the phone is almost a month old. My iPhone 5c was super reliable for over 5 years!! The Pixel 3XL is so disappointing, especially because the night camera feature was one thing I was really looking forward to. Just don't do it. Learn from my mistake. I spent 6 hours on the phone today trying to get help and even had to do a complete factory reset. Nothing helps. It's a hardware issue and the manufacturer DOES NOT CARE. Do not buy a Google product because they will not stand behind their product unless you can live without your phone for 2 weeks. Ironically, my iPhone 5c still works, but Verizon won't reconnect such an old phone so I can send my brand new phone back to Google. Hilarious. The phone that works cannot be connected and my new phone can't even snap a selfie.

1951.title: Pixel 3 camera slow to start / shooting lag

I read in a number of different forums that the Pixel 3 camera app sometimes takes a few seconds to start, which will often make you miss a shot involving  kids moving rapidly. Another issue I've read about is that once you tap the "shoot" button, the actual shot is not instantaneous, but it happens a few hundreds milliseconds later. Again, when you have a moving kid, a ~200ms lag can too much.
Has anyone here experienced these issues? Would you recommend the Pixel 3 to someone who has such strict performance requirements for the camera app?
Thank you!

2022.title: Pixel 1 manual and auto focus aren't working
2022.content:
Ok so, for unrelated reasons, a few years ago I had my first pixel replaced with a refurbished version.

The refurbished phone had issues with focusing within a month of using it.

By that point, I was out of warranty to get it fixed. Google support staff had me try everything including clear my cache, reinstall the camera app, use safe mode, factory reset, etc. None of those steps worked.

* Critical Point: A third party app called Open Camera allows you to manually control the camera focus. This is NOT automatic focus. It's manual. Manual focus on the third party app couldn't even adjust the focus. So the issue isn't the laser sensors. It's the camera itself.

What I want is simple: an acknowledgment that this phone has a fundamental fault with its camera that isn't a software issue.

For years, you guys have refused to acknowledge that it's a hardware problem, and have consistently insisted the problem is from software.

You guys wouldn't stand by your product or acknowledge it was faulty, and tried to get me to pay for repairs on a phone that was broken out of the box.

All I know is that, until you acknowledge my complete disgust with the way you handled this, I'll never buy a pixel as long as I live.

Oh yeah, I've also shared my experiences with others and talked two people out of buying the Pixel 3.

2075.title: S21 Ultra Camera Issues
2075.content:
Hi all,
I'm new to the forum but just had to join because I have been experiencing some really annoying issues with my brand new S21 Ultra's camera. I'm very familiar with each of the camera modules and what they're good for, however mine can't seem to use the right one at the right time.
It keeps choosing to use the 3x telephoto lense when I ask for 10x zoom, and often uses the 10x lense when I ask for 3x. The result is ridiculously grainy images that don't even compare to my Note 10+.  I have tried experimenting by covering up the camera lenses that I think it should be using at the time to prove that it's getting it wrong, and low and behold the image isn't covered up.
The annoying thing is, I can see the camera switching between the correct and incorrect modules if I tilt the camera towards different light. 
  Has anyone else experienced this? Hopefully fixable with a software update but this is really affecting the quality of my images.

2083.title: S21 Ultra AUC8 Impression
2083.content:
So far I've noticed 3 changes from AUBB.
1. AUBB somehow caused my phone to (again...!) heat up to roughly 45c-46c with a few minutes of video / extensive camera use. Never had an overheating warning but still 46 is not something that is nice to handle.
With AUC8 that seems to be resolved once again. Long duration video and a Wildlife stress test (20 loops) reached a maximum of 42c. 
2. The obvious portrait mode change. I actually really like the ability to choose between the 3 lenses
3. Shutter is quicker with considerably reduced lag.
Anyone noticed anything else?

2087.title: Some Exynos 2100 love!

The photos are flaming stunning on every lense and in every mode. I have heard people say that the Exynos version is inferior to the Snapdragon version (at the moment) in terms of video capture but that it can get the nod in terms of photo quality. My camera got too warm at first when I got the phone but I just kept using the thing (gently at first but now pushing it) and it seems to be really settling down big time temperature wise. 2090.title: S21 ultra low Dxomark score
2090.content: So we've all seen the low score of the S21 ultra, compared to huawei and the iphone 12 pro max. Even more concerning is the comparison to the s20 ultra. However I think it is completely unfair as the whole zoom category checked the phone in the completely wrong way. Look at the test. It does 2.5x,4x and 8x. ALL are ranges where the phone goes digital and crops. Obviously if other phones have a 2x lens that is used for 2.5x/4x/8x the results would be more 'optical'. What they should have done is to test the camera charateristics at 3x and 10x. Not compared to anything but to give an objective assessment of those lenses. They also completely ignored ultra zoom (say X30) comparison between the phones. I also didnt see any note on the macro capabilities. True, there are things to improve (noise, video details) and I hope they are improved in software. However I do feel that with a fair comparison of the zoom lenses the overall score would be very similar to the Iphone.

2092.title: S21 Ultra Camera 10x Optical Issues
2092.content:
Hi,
Have somebody noticed that Samsung s21 Ultra (Exynos version) is not consistent with its 10x optical zoom, especially in low light environments?
If the camera software does not detect enough light, it automatically switches to the 3x optical lens setup and then zooms digitally up to 10x. That's why  a lot of people are also complaining about grainy shots! (when using telephoto lenses)
Samsung, why not to give the option to the customer to decide how he wants to use the lenses? (Make this a setting...)
Also, add the telephoto lenses to the Pro Camera, and release an update!

  S21 & S21+: triple-lens, AI-enhanced pro-grade camera system built for every user, so anyone (even me maybe?) can capture, edit, and share amazing shots, and in steady 8K video; edge-to-edge, Dynamic AMOLED 2X adaptive 120Hz display; the most advanced processor ever in a Galaxy device, so you can download quickly and game and stream seamlessly.
  S21 Ultra: quad-lens advanced pro-grade AI-enhanced camera system, which includes ultra-wide and wide lenses, as well as Dual Zoom-lenses (one optical 3x and one optical 10x; adaptive display that supports a refresh rate from 10Hz to 120Hz at Quad HD+ quality; Wi-Fi 6E and Ultra Wide Band (UWB); S Pen support…

2103.title: S20+ Which camera use and how to set it up?
2103.content:
I haven't written anything about photography for a while, so I feel it's the time to fix it. After all, when, if not when the new generation of Galaxy S has arrived?
Zoom
The Samsung Galaxy S20+ has 3 cameras: main, wide angle and zoom.
So first we look at the zoom camera.
I took 3 photos for you, each with a different zoom. So my S20 + should always use a different camera module.
zoom 0.5x
zoom 1x
zoom 3x
As you can see, there is half the street on the widest focus, 3 houses on the basic module and 3 windows on the zoom.
Let's see what it looks like if we put the 3 photos on top of each other:
Here it is even better to see the difference between modules. So don't be afraid to use all three modules. Switch between them easily by clicking the tree icon. The fewer trees, the more detailed you take a photo.
But beware! This applies if there is enough light! Under low light conditions, the wide-angle (f / 2.2) and telephoto (f / 2.0) lenses will appear less bright. It doesn't seem like that, because the basic lens has an f / 1.8, but even this few difference indicate almost half the light transmission of a wide-angle lens.
Of course, if you need a wide shot, the widescreen module is irreplaceable, but if you want to zoom, consider if you prefer to use cropping or just have less detail.
Aspect Ratio
And now let's look at another setting, namely the aspect ratio. You may have noticed that the camera settings only have the option to set the resolution for video, but no longer for photos. All that is available is the aspect ratio setting. We can choose from ratios of 4: 3, 16: 9, 1: 1 and Full.
  What is what and when to use? Again we will first show the pictures:
1:1
4:3
16:9
Full
Well, what's going on? The table with the resolution of each picture will tell us more:
As we can see, the 4:3 aspect ratio has the highest resolution. 1:1 is the same in height but smaller in width, then 16:9 and Full are preserved in width, but the height is reduced.
Here is again one picture with all images:
The whole photo is 4:3, others are highlighted by colored rectangles. Here I would like to point out that, as in the first case with zoom, I did not just paint lines into one photo, but I really stacked the individual photos on top of each other. After all, it's a bit visible, because I don't have a proper tripod at home right now, so the cell phone moved a bit during the photo shoot.
The 4:3 aspect ratio uses the entire area of the chip, other ratios crop the photo.
So the idea is to always take photos in a 4: 3 ratio and if necessary crop the photos at home. I recommend it and I do it, but there are exceptions.
We can use the 1:1 aspect ratio if we know we want to share the photo only on Instagram.
The 16:9 aspect ratio makes sense if we present photos on TV (they usually have this aspect ratio).
Full uses exactly the entire area of the mobile phone display, if we show photos on it, it makes sense.
  But it is important to realize that anything other than 4:3 means irreversibly discarding some information.
SAMSUNG Galaxy Z Fold3 5G 512 Black | Galaxy Z Flip
Galaxy Buds | Galaxy Buds+ | Galaxy Buds Pro

2105.title: S20 Ultra Camera Suggestion - Pro mode for wide angle and telephoto lenses
2105.content:
Since getting the phone (S20 Ultra) and dealing with some autofocus issues, I've come to appreciate the pro mode. Not for any of the pro features, really (I'm no photographer and don't get how to use all the features properly) but for the fact that it has manual focus. When auto focus fails (which it regularly does on the current firmware) it's great to be able to have a backup option. There are 2 problems with the pro mode, however:
  1) You can only use the main camera sensor
2) You can't use 108mp mode on the main sensor
  Personally, I think it would be great if Samsung enabled pro mode on the telephoto and wide angle lenses - especially the telephoto lens. While it wouldn't negate the need for better autofocus on the normal mode (which the phone desparately needs) it would at least give people an option when the camera is unable to focus, or in situations where the camera just keeps focusing on the wrong thing (which can happen on the best of autofocus implementations).

2106.title: S20 Ultra Camera focus issues - especially at close range
2106.content:
Just received my S20 Ultra and have been experimenting with the camera a little. I have noticed that it is really, really bad at focusing on anything at relatively close range. If I try the same shot with the S10+ it's absolutely fine - I can get pretty insane quality pictures on the 2x lens on that from about 5cm away. This appears to be an issue on all lenses but is certainly much worse when it's using the 4x lens - as soon as it goes beyond the 4.0 point on anything less than 30-50cm away it just becomes a blurry mess, which wasn't an issue on any of my previous phones. Right now the camera feels like a downgrade in this regard...
  Has anyone else had this? Or is there a firmware due to patch it? One of the main reasons I got the S20 Ultra was for the incredible camera but right now I'm quite disappointed with its performance. I did hear that a patch was due but I don't see any when trying to update - maybe it's just not been rolled out yet.
  EDIT: Just had a look around and noticed that I was looking at the wrong part of the software version number, assuming I already had the update and it was still bad. It looks like the phones come shipped with firmware version ending in ATBM and the firmware that fixes the camera issues is ATC2
  Either way if possible I'd still like to know an ETA on the update.
